CHIEF COMPLAINT:  The patient is a 14 -year-old gentleman who
was admitted on [**2182-7-15**] status post a motor vehicle crash.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 14 -year-old
male who was an unrestrained passenger in a roll over motor
vehicle accident where the roof of the car was basically
wrapped around a pole.  There was a significant amount of car
damage and he had a prolonged extrication, approximately 30
minutes.  He denies loss of consciousness.  He was speaking
and moving all extremities on the scene.  He was brought in
by EMS, boarded and collared.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Non-significant.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Non-significant.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

ADMITTING MEDICATIONS:  No medications previous to
hospitalization.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  On presentation he was uncomfortable,
vital signs were a heart rate of 100, blood pressure 130/65,
respiratory rate was 20, saturating 96%.  [**Location (un) 2611**] coma scale
was 15.  He was speaking coherently and moving all
extremities.  Physical examination of the head revealed a
left, approximately 12 cm laceration in the parietal area
down to the skull.  Pupils were equal, round, and reactive to
light, extraocular muscles were intact, tympanic membranes
were clear.  There were no battles or raccoon signs.  There
was no facial tenderness.  Oropharynx was clear.  Neck was in
a cervical collar, nontender, trachea was midline.

Chest examination: there were clear breath sounds bilaterally
with decreased breath sounds on the left.  There were no
palpable deformities or tenderness and there was no crepitus.
Cardiovascular: he had a regular rate and rhythm, plus S1,
S2.  Abdominal examination was soft, tender in the lower
quadrants bilaterally, there was no rigidity and there was
positive voluntary guarding.  Pelvis was stable, tender.
Extremities: there was a right forearm abrasion.  Rectal had
normal tone.  Palpable pulses bilaterally, upper and lower
extremities.  Back: there was T3, T4 midline tenderness,
otherwise no stepoff.

ADMISSION LABORATORY DATA:  White blood cell count was 11.7,
hematocrit 38.1, platelets 248,000.  BUN and creatinine were
18 and 0.8.  Coags were PT of 13, PTT was 22.8, INR was 1.1.
Fibrinogen was 204.  Urinalysis was within normal limits.
Amylase was 36.

Radiology:  trauma cervical spine was negative for a fracture
or dislocation to C7.  Chest x-ray revealed a left chest tube
which was placed in the Trauma Bay for the decreased breath
sounds.  There was no pneumothorax, no opacifications.  The
pelvis had no fracture or dislocation.  CT scan of the head
revealed no hemorrhage and there was a lot of motion artifact
in the lower part of the CT scan.  CT scan of the abdomen was
negative.

IMPRESSION:  Impression on presentation was that of a 14
-year-old man, status post an unrestrained roll over motor
vehicle crash with a head laceration on the left and a left
rib fracture 7 through 9, status post a left chest tube
placement in the Trauma Bay based on clinical examination and
findings.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the Intensive
Care Unit for a q one hour neurologic checks.  He had
thoracic, lumbar, and sacral films done, cervical spine
precautions, log roll precautions.  He was given morphine prn
for pain.  Cardiovascularly he was stable.  Respiratory wise
a chest tube was placed to suction.  O2 saturations were
monitored.  Gastrointestinal wise, the patient was placed on
NPO, serial abdominal examination, his Foley was placed to
gravity bed side bag.  Hematocrit checked, CBC, in the AM.

Infectious Disease: tetanus was given, Kefzol was given times
one.  Fluids, electrolytes, and nutrition: the patient was
receiving lactated Ringers 125 cc an hour.  Radiology: there
was thoracic, lumbar, sacral and complete cervical spines to
do.  Prophylaxis: the patient was on Zantac and Venodyne.
Also in the Trauma Bay the patient underwent a scalp stapling
for his large head laceration.

On hospital day one, there were no new events.  Vital signs
showed a temperature of 100.3 F, heart rate of 89, blood
pressure 130/60, rate of 22, saturating 100% on four liters
of nasal cannula.  The patient had approximately
.................... chest tube and that was basically an
overnight shift.  He remained alert, awake, and oriented.
His left chest tube was without an air leak and was putting
out serosanguinous drainage.  His abdominal examination was
benign.  Chest was clear.  Extremities were warm.

CT Surgery was consulted in reference to the chest tube which
was put on water seal on hospital day two.  The chest x-ray
was done several hours after water seal which was negative
for pneumothorax and the chest tube was eventually pulled.
The patient was kept on Zantac and morphine patient
controlled anesthesia for pain.  He was also given Toradol
and droperidol.  Lactated Ringers was running at a lesser
rate of 60.  Abdominal examination was unchanged.  Chest and
neurologic examination was unchanged.  The extremities were
warm.  His neck was tender over the left paraspinal soft
tissue, but there was no bony tenderness and his cervical
spine was cleared after flexion and extension films.

Hematocrit needed to be checked, which were okay.  His IV was
hep-locked, his diet was advanced, Foley was discontinued,
and it was determined on hospital day two that the patient
should be transferred to a pediatric hospital floor given
that the patient's age was less than 15 years old and it
turns out that hospital policy only allows patients greater
than 15 years old to stay in our facility.  Therefore, [**Hospital 14852**] was contact[**Name (NI) **] and they accepted this
patient to their hospital via the Emergency Department.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Status post motor vehicle crash.
2.  Status post multiple thoracic rib fractures.
3.  Status post chest tube placement.
4.  Status post a large scalp laceration.
5.  Status post stapling of the scalp laceration.

TRANSFER CONDITION:  Stable.

PLAN:  The patient's plan was to go to the floor today and
the patient will be going to a floor in the outside hospital.
